clinical_study.brief_title: Network-Level Mechanisms for Preclinical Alzheimer's Disease Development
clinical_study.official_title: Network-Level Mechanisms for Preclinical Alzheimer's Disease Development

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this project is to test the hypothesis that a low dose of levetiracetam can reduce abnormal hyperfunctional activity in the hippocampus in normal, healthy adults who are APOE 4 carriers. The investigators will compare the results to normal, healthy adults who are APOE 4 non-carriers.

detailed_description.textblock:
In this study the investigators want to find out whether the use of a low dose of levetiracetam (LEV) in healthy adults with the Apolipoprotein e4 gene (APOE 4) can reduce abnormal hippocampal network activity. The investigators also want to study whether this low dose of LEV can improve memory function.
LEV is a type of drug called an anti-epileptic or anti-seizure medication. It is FDA approved worldwide for adults and children as young as one month with seizures. It is a generic drug used in long-term epilepsy treatment. It is relatively safe and has an acceptable side-effect profile.
It is known that age and the APOE 4 gene are important risk factors for late-onset Alzheimer's disease. Further studies have shown that cognitively normal, older adults with the APOE 4 gene have more hyperfunctional brain network activity, increased alpha beta accumulation, decreased memory function, and decreased brain volume, which is consistent with Alzheimer's disease patterns.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: This is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled crossover study in which a low dose of LEV (125 mg, BID) or placebo will be administered to 50 healthy 55-75-year-old subjects (comprising 25 APOE 4 carriers and 25 noncarriers), with the order of treatments counterbalanced in a within-subject crossover design.
study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: Functional connectivity strengths of neural networks
primary_outcome.time_frame: At the baseline and 2 weeks after treatment
primary_outcome.description: The seed-based functional connectivity strengths of the hippocampus network and the default mode network will be employed to measure the changes before and after the levetiracetam (LEV) perturbation. The functional connectivity strengths will be measured with the median of the Pearson cross-correlation coefficients over entire brain regions and the maps of the functional connectivity strengths.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: At the baseline and 2 weeks after treatment
secondary_outcome.description: AVLT will be employed to measure the episodic memory changes before and after LEV treatment. The AVLT score will be recorded and later integrated with LMT score to provide the composite EM score. The EM score for a subject is a standardized z-score converted from AVLT and LMT scores.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: At the baseline and 2 weeks after treatment
secondary_outcome.description: LMT will be employed to measure the episodic memory changes before and after LEV treatment. The LMT score will be recorded and later integrated with AVLT score to provide the composite EM score. The EM score for a subject is a standardized z-score converted from AVLT and LMT scores.

arm_group.description: Levetiracetam (LEV), 250 mg/day capsule, given as twice-daily dosing (125 mg twice daily) for two weeks.
Placebo given as a capsule, twice-daily for two weeks.

intervention.description: Levetiracetam (LEV) oral dose of 250 mg/day capsule, given as twice-daily dosing (125 mg twice daily).

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Healthy adult
- Normal memory
- Fluent in English
- At least eight (8) years of education
- Normal cognitive function
Exclusion Criteria:
- Diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease, mild cognitive impairment, or other dementia
- Neurological disease, such as Parkinson's disease, multi-infarct dementia, Huntington's disease, normal pressure hydrocephalus, brain tumor, progressive supranuclear palsy, seizure disorder, subdural hematoma, multiple sclerosis
- History of significant head trauma
- Known structural brain abnormalities
- Major psychiatric disease
- Current depression
- History of stroke
- History of drug abuse
- Pacemaker/Defibrillator
- Unable to complete MRI scans
